data.title: City of Toledo shutting down illegal after-hours clubs
data.meta_description: The City of Toledo is cracking down on after-hours establishments, starting with the Glass House Lounge on Telegraph Road. "We know where you are, and as we have already done this year, we are prepared to throw the entire weight of the City of Toledo at you to take away your property and to do that in the name of public safety," Mayor Wade Kapszukiewicz said. This comes less than three days after a deadly shooting at the location that injured three people and killed 41-year-old Carthrice Warren.
data.text:
The City of Toledo is cracking down on after-hours establishments, starting with the Glass House Lounge on Telegraph Road.

"We know where you are, and as we have already done this year, we are prepared to throw the entire weight of the City of Toledo at you to take away your property and to do that in the name of public safety," Mayor Wade Kapszukiewicz said.

This comes less than three days after a deadly shooting at the location that injured three people and killed 41-year-old Carthrice Warren.

"We know these clubs only breed illegal activity. We're talking drugs, we're talking sexual trafficking and murders, now there's a 41-year-old woman's family who mourns her death at the hands of a greedy and unprincipled operator," said Theresa Morris, Toledo City Council District 6.

Toledo Fire and Police are standing by the efforts calling on citizens to do their part to help keep the city safe, with many of the illegal establishments violating safety codes and only opening up on obscure days and times.

"We can't be everywhere at the same time, but once we know that a place is up and going, we can reach out to our friends at the Ohio State Highway Patrol and the Ohio Investigative Unit and try to get in there," TPD Chief George Kral said.

The city is calling on six other locations they know that operate as after-hours clubs to shut down or they'll be forced to shut down.

"It shelters residents in place because residents are scared to go out into their neighborhoods to do things with their families, so it puts just a negative spotlight on our community," said Alfonso Narvaez, president of ONE Village Council.

The city is urging residents to call and report any illegal after-hours club you may know of and to not go into them.
